Class manual_reset_event

boost::sync::manual_reset_event

Synopsis

// In header: <boost/sync/events/manual_reset_event.hpp>


class manual_reset_event {
public:
  // construct/copy/destruct
  manual_reset_event();
  manual_reset_event(manual_reset_event const &) = delete;
  manual_reset_event & operator=(manual_reset_event const &) = delete;
  ~manual_reset_event();

  // public member functions
  void set();
  void reset();
  void wait();
  bool try_wait();
  template<typename Time> bool timed_wait(const Time &);
  template<typename Duration> bool wait_for(const Duration &);
  template<typename TimePoint> bool wait_until(const TimePoint &);
};

Description

manual_reset_event public construct/copy/destruct

  1. manual_reset_event();

    Constructs an event object in a non-signalled state.

    Throws: if an error occurs. 

  2. manual_reset_event(manual_reset_event const &) = delete;
  3. manual_reset_event & operator=(manual_reset_event const &) = delete;
  4. ~manual_reset_event();

    Destroys the event object.

    Requires:

    No threads are blocked on this object.

manual_reset_event public member functions

  1. void set();

    Sets the event object to the signalled state. While the event is set, any number of threads that are or would be blocked in one of the wait functions can be released while the event is in signalled state. Setting an already signalled event has no effect.

    Memory Ordering: release

    Throws: if an error occurs.

    Note

    If multiple threads are waiting on the event, this call does not guarantee that all these threads will be unblocked. It is possible that some of the woken threads resets the event to the non-signalled state before the other threads are unblocked. 

  2. void reset();

    Resets the event to the non-signaled state. Resetting a non-signalled event has no effect.

    Memory Ordering: relaxed

    Throws: if an error occurs. 

  3. void wait();

    If the event is signalled, returns. Otherwise waits for the event to become signalled.

    Memory Ordering: acquire

    Throws: if an error occurs. 

  4. bool try_wait();

    Attempts to wait for the event to become signalled.

    Memory Ordering: acquire, if successful, relaxed otherwise

    Throws: if an error occurs.

    Returns:

    true if the event is signalled, otherwise false.

    		 
  5. template<typename Time> bool timed_wait(const Time & timeout);

    If the event is signalled, the call returns. Otherwise the call blocks until the event is set to the signalled state or the timeout expires.

    Memory Ordering: acquire, if successful, relaxed otherwise

    Throws: if an error occurs.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    timeout

    The timeout for the operation to complete. The timeout can be specified either as an absolute time point or as a duration. In the latter case the time is measured according to the system clock.

    Returns:

    true if the event is signalled, otherwise false.

    		 
  6. template<typename Duration> bool wait_for(const Duration & duration);

    If the event is signalled, the call returns. Otherwise the call blocks until the event is set to the signalled state or the timeout expires.

    Memory Ordering: acquire, if successful, relaxed otherwise

    Throws: if an error occurs.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    duration

    The timeout for the operation to complete. The timeout should be a duration, which is measured according to the system clock.

    Returns:

    true if the event is signalled, otherwise false.

    		 
  7. template<typename TimePoint> bool wait_until(const TimePoint & timeout);

    If the event is signalled, the call returns. Otherwise the call blocks until the event is set to the signalled state or the timeout expires.

    Memory Ordering: acquire, if successful, relaxed otherwise

    Throws: if an error occurs.

    Note

    In order to use this method, a supplementary header must be included from boost/sync/support to enable support for particular time units.

    Parameters:

    timeout

    The timeout for the operation to complete. The timeout should be an absolute time point.

    Returns:

    true if the event is signalled, otherwise false.
